title: Seychelles Founding President appeal: Put Seychelles First
text:
Seychelles Founding President appeal: Put Seychelles First   
Oct 19, 2015 eTN   
Transiting through Vienna on the way to Belgrade for the summit meeting of the European Council for Peace and Development (ECPD), following his participation at the Ocean Exchange gathering in Savana Georgia, USA Seychelles Founding President Sir James R Mancham has launched an appeal to the people of Seychelles to face the coming presidential election which is due in the first week of December 2015, in a manner commensurate with the "Put Seychelles First" philosophy. 
"The Presidential election does not provide us with a license during the election campaign to "assassinate" the character of one's opponent be he the current President or another Presidential Candidate", Mr Mancham stated. 
According to him, the occasion should be more of a moment for national reflexion. The electorate must face the realization that it is always easier to destroy than to build and the candidate must not be tempted to see the spot on an opponent's face when there are many blemishes on his own. 
According to Sir James the Seychellois people must count their blessings in living in such a beautiful country but beauty is not everything if we are living in an atmosphere of hatred, dislike and hostility. 
We should listen to the words of God and endeavor to spread love where there is hatred and unity and harmony where there is discord and anger. 
Taking into account what has recently been said at political meetings and what has been written in different partisan newspapers it would appear, according to Sir James that many have lost their ability to discuss important issues calmly and respectfully regardless of their party affiliations or other differences. 
We are a small country and although our economy looks good at this time, we must appreciate the need for stability if we are to consolidate on recent achievements. This will require that we all come together in an atmosphere of harmony to solve our problems", Mr Mancham stated. 
I believe "that the Republic of Seychelles should aim to be One Nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all." 
In this respect I am appealing to all fellow seychelles citizen to show decency and common sense over the next few weeks and thereafter."
